Award.AwardTitle: The Effect of Alumina Substitution on Viscoelasticity of Calcium Silicate Hydrate

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to link the chemical composition and molecular structure of calcium silicate hydrate (C-S-H) to the viscoelastic mechanical properties of the material. C-S-H is the main binding hydration product of portland cement that governs properties of concrete. If alumina is available during the production of C-S-H, typically from alumino-silicate supplementary cementitious materials, C-S-H is able to incorporate aluminum as a guest ion, producing a calcium aluminosilicate hydrate (C-A-S-H). Alumina incorporation is seen to alter its molecular structure by increasing the tetrahedral chain length, a change that is seen to promote crosslinking between C-S-H layers. By applying a multiscale static and dynamic mechanical testing that include a novel nanomechanical characterization technique of dynamic nanoindentation, the main hypothesis that will be tested during this project is to determine whether C-A-S-H is less viscoelastic than C-S-H due to this increased polymerization. To relate chemical composition and molecular structure with viscoelastic properties, phase-pure C-S-H and C-A-S-H will be synthesized in the lab with varying composition and characterized using advanced techniques such as nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) for local atomic environment, X-ray diffraction (XRD) for detection of crystalline phases, and X-ray fluorescence (XRF) for bulk chemical composition. Furthermore, a combination of NMR characterization before and after mechanical testing will indicate if there are any changes in molecular structure during viscoelastic deformation, knowledge that will be transformative.

If the hypothesis that alumina substitution in C-S-H reduces creep is proved right, this research will lead to a new method of controlling the viscoelasticity of concrete that can ultimately lead to longer life of concrete structures. Concrete is the most widely used construction material in the world and production of it is associated with approximately 5% of the global CO2 emissions. Thus, any increase in the longevity of concrete structure will mean reduction in the amount of concrete produced and associated greenhouse gas emission. In addition, the main source of alumina in C-S-H is usually fly ash, a waste material that also reduces the portland cement content in concrete and thereby reduces its greenhouse gas emission. The research is well integrated with educational plans, including (a) training graduate student in advanced chemo-mechanical characterization of materials at multiscale, (b) incorporating research findings into graduate level classes, and (c) generating enthusiasm for engineering and sustainable construction among talented middle school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project was to link the chemical composition and molecular structure of calcium silicate hydrate (C-S-H) to the viscoelastic mechanical properties of the material. C-S-H is the main binding hydration product of Portland cement that governs properties of concrete. If alumina is available during the production of C-S-H, it is able to incorporate aluminum as a guest ion, producing a calcium aluminosilicate hydrate (C-A-S-H). Alumina incorporation is seen to alter its molecular structure by increasing the tetrahedral chain length, a change that is seen to promote crosslinking between C-S-H layers. The main hypothesis that was tested during this project was whether C-A-S-H is less viscoelastic than C-S-H due to its altered molecular structure. To relate chemical composition and molecular structure with viscoelastic properties, phase-pure C-S-H and C-A-S-H was synthesized in the lab with varying composition and characterized using advanced techniques such as nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) for local atomic environment, X-ray diffraction (XRD) for detection of crystalline phases, and X-ray fluorescence (XRF) for bulk chemical composition. Novel static and dynamic mechanical testing along with reverse-micromechanics modeling was employed to understand the influence of nanostructure on elastic and viscoelastic behavior of synthesized C-(A)-S-H.

 

The direct benefit of the successful completion of this project is mainly two-fold. First, viscoelastic behavior of synthesized C-A-S-H was measured for the first time and the changes in the nanostructure were proved to cause a decrease in time-dependent response. This result is of critical significance as it could lead to a new method of controlling the viscoelasticity of concrete that can ultimately lead to a longer life of concrete structures. Concrete is the most widely used construction material in the world and production of it is associated with approximately 5% of the global carbon dioxide emissions. Thus, an increase in the longevity of concrete structure will mean a reduction in the amount of concrete produced and associated greenhouse gas emission. In addition, the main source of alumina in C-S-H is usually fly ash, a waste material that also reduces the Portland cement content in concrete and thereby reduces its greenhouse gas emission. In future, more research should be performed to verify that the influence of changes to the nanostructure of C-(A)-S-H is also extended to the viscoelasticity of hydrated cement paste and concrete as concrete viscoelasticity is also affected by other factors such as water movement and dissolution of viscoelastic phases under load.

 

Second, the experimental methods developed in this project has a broader significance as it enhanced the state-of-the-art knowledge in the field of nanomechanical properties of porous materials. It was experimentally established for the first time that the normalized time-dependent modulus from indentation experiments provides a means to compare the time-dependent behavior of any porous material and is an effective way to isolate changes in the solid phase from the influence of porosity. It was shown that the time-dependent modulus of the solid phase that is obtained from creep experiments and reverse-micromechanics modeling of a compacted pellet provides both instantaneous and time-dependent behavior of the solid component of a porous material and can be used in multiscale modeling of complex composite systems. The research was well integrated with educational plans, including (a) training two graduate students in advanced chemo-mechanical characterization of materials at multiscale, (b) incorporating research findings into two graduate level classes by the PI, and (c) generating enthusiasm for research among undergraduate students by hiring two undergraduate students to participate actively in the laboratory for assisting graduate students. 

 


Last Modified: 11/20/2018
Modified by: Paramita Mondal
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The objective of this project was to link the chemical composition and molecular structure of calcium silicate hydrate (C-S-H) to the viscoelastic mechanical properties of the material. C-S-H is the main binding hydration product of Portland cement that governs properties of concrete. If alumina is available during the production of C-S-H, it is able to incorporate aluminum as a guest ion, producing a calcium aluminosilicate hydrate (C-A-S-H). Alumina incorporation is seen to alter its molecular structure by increasing the tetrahedral chain length, a change that is seen to promote crosslinking between C-S-H layers. The main hypothesis that was tested during this project was whether C-A-S-H is less viscoelastic than C-S-H due to its altered molecular structure. To relate chemical composition and molecular structure with viscoelastic properties, phase-pure C-S-H and C-A-S-H was synthesized in the lab with varying composition and characterized using advanced techniques such as nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) for local atomic environment, X-ray diffraction (XRD) for detection of crystalline phases, and X-ray fluorescence (XRF) for bulk chemical composition. Novel static and dynamic mechanical testing along with reverse-micromechanics modeling was employed to understand the influence of nanostructure on elastic and viscoelastic behavior of synthesized C-(A)-S-H. The direct benefit of the successful completion of this project is mainly two-fold. First, viscoelastic behavior of synthesized C-A-S-H was measured for the first time and the changes in the nanostructure were proved to cause a decrease in time-dependent response. This result is of critical significance as it could lead to a new method of controlling the viscoelasticity of concrete that can ultimately lead to a longer life of concrete structures. Concrete is the most widely used construction material in the world and production of it is associated with approximately 5% of the global carbon dioxide emissions. Second, the experimental methods developed in this project has a broader significance as it enhanced the state-of-the-art knowledge in the field of nanomechanical properties of porous materials. It was experimentally established for the first time that the normalized time-dependent modulus from indentation experiments provides a means to compare the time-dependent behavior of any porous material and is an effective way to isolate changes in the solid phase from the influence of porosity. It was shown that the time-dependent modulus of the solid phase that is obtained from creep experiments and reverse-micromechanics modeling of a compacted pellet provides both instantaneous and time-dependent behavior of the solid component of a porous material and can be used in multiscale modeling of complex composite systems. The research was well integrated with educational plans, including (a) training two graduate students in advanced chemo-mechanical characterization of materials at multiscale, (b) incorporating research findings into two graduate level classes by the PI, and (c) generating enthusiasm for research among undergraduate students by hiring two undergraduate students to participate actively in the laboratory for assisting graduate students.
